phrase.item: Once upon a time, long ago, a fox and a bear lived together in a village.
They had a parcel of land together under a rocky mountain.
Every year after the new year, when they were about to start working on their field, the bear would say, "Hey friend, look up there, do you see the big stone up the hill?"
"Now you start working and I go and hold the rock so it doesn't roll down."
"It will hurt us as well as our yaks."
Soon, the bear tricked the fox.
He climbed up the hill and slept by the rock.
The poor fox worked on the field alone. He planted wheat until the autumn watered it.
Then he cut the grass, carried the dry grass to the flat field [an area set aside for separating wheat from grass], separated the wheat from the grass, and collected the harvest.
The bear would come down and breathe deeply as if he was very tired.
He said, "Oh friend, you worked down here without any problem."
"Without me all your work is useless."
The fox also believed this.
The bear said, "Hey friend, let's divide the harvest now."
"The top is for me and the bottom (root) is for you."
Soon, the bear took the wheat and gave the plain grass to the fox.
The poor fox brought the plain grass home.
His wife told him, "Your friend is tricking you and you believe him."
The fox scolded his wife and said, "If not for my friend, the big rock would roll down and hit our house and our yaks too."
So, after that, they lived through a harsh winter.
Again spring came and it was the new year.
It was time to work in the field. The fox and bear went to plant their field.
The bear said, "Hey friend, let's plant carrots this year."
"You start working, I will go and hold the rock so it doesn't fall down."
He tricked the fox again.
The fox planted alone, sowed, and weeded. So, he kept working hard and autumn came.
He harvested [the carrots].
The bear came gown and took a deep breath, saying he was very tired. Then they divided the harvest into portions.
The bear told the fox, "Hey friend, last year you got the root and I got the head."
"This year I will take the root and you take the head."
Corrected from: wsərd wuz dɨrzəm sari tu dɨrz bixi. [This year I will take the head and you take the root.]
The bear again tricked his friend.
He [the bear] took the carrots and gave the plain grass to the fox.
Then the fox realized that his friend had been tricking him all this time.
Then the [fox] said, "Until today I haven't tricked anyone yet."
"From now on, when I start lying, nobody's father [i.e., nobody in the world] will be able to [match me]."
The fox said, "Okay friend, we have collected a nice harvest this year, let's rest for a while and then divide it into portions.
They lay down in the [flat field] and started chatting; suddenly a bird was flying over their heads.
Not sure if amo is just a bird or a specific kind of bird.
The fox said, "Oh, unfaithful world, don't do any favor for anyone in this world."
"Look at this bird now."
"It is not even saying hi."
The bear asked, "How do you know this bird?"
The fox relied, "It's not just that I know it, this bird was my student, I taught it how to fly."
The bear said, "Hey friend, you are so unkind."
"You're saying yourself that the world is unfaithful; we have been friends for so many years but you never told me."
"Why don't you teach me how to fly too?"
"Every time I come by I will say hi to you."
The fox said to himself, "Well, now I can trick you nicely."
"I will teach you so you will never forget it."
Then he said, "Hey friend, no problem, I can teach you. You don't have wings, I have to make you wings."
He said, "Now you carry these wings on your shoulder, and take it up to this high mountain."
He siad, "You will have to carry me as well, otherwise I won't go."
The bear carried the wings and his friend the fox and climbed up the high rocky mountain.

The fox tied the wings to the bear's back and said, "Hey friend, now I will go down to the bottom and, when I wave my hand at you, you can jump off this rocky mointain, go around once and don't say hi; when you go around the second time then you can say hi to me."
Soon, the bear jumped from the high place and disappeared.
The fox had gotten rid of him.
From that day on the fox never trusted anyone.
And no one was his equal at lying.
